chapter: Multiple Myeloma and Plasma Cell Disorders

questions.question: Question 1: What is the normal ratio between kappa and lambda light chains?
questions.explanation:
The normal ratio of kappa to lambda light chains is 60:40. In multiple myeloma, usually this ratio is skewed, i.e., favorable secretion of one type of light 
chain occurs at the expense of the other. Serum-free light chain assay is a recommended part of 
the initial diagnostic workup for multiple myeloma. 562 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 3: A 76-year-old man presents for a routine health check-up and is found to be mildly anemic. 
Physical examination reveals no abnormalities. Serum protein electrophoresis with 
immunofixation demonstrates an IgG-kappa monoclonal protein with markedly reduced IgM 
and IgA levels. Bone marrow biopsy shows 12% plasma cells. A skeletal survey reveals 
osteopenia and several punched-out lytic lesions, but no fractures. What is the most likely 
diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of multiple myeloma. Plasma cell dyscrasias are B-cell proliferations that contain neoplastic plasma cells that secrete a 
monoclonal Ig or Ig fragment. Multiple myeloma is a malignant neoplasm of plasma cells 
characterized by the presence of monoclonal immunoglobulin or light chains in the serum and 
urine. It is a disease of older adults, with a peak age of incidence of 65 to 70 years. Signs and symptoms include: • Hypercalcemia • Pathologic fractures/ lytic bone lesions • Renal failure • Anemia Investigations reveal: • Radiography - Punched-out lytic lesions on X-ray • Electrophoresis - Monoclonal elevation of one immunoglobulin • Urinalysis - Free kappa and lambda light chains (Bence Jones proteins) • Bone marrow biopsy - 10 to 20%plasma cells (normal is < 5%) • Peripheral smear - Rouleaux formation. A high level of M proteins in myeloma causes red cells 
in the peripheral blood smears to stick to one another in linear arrays, a finding referred to as 
rouleaux formation. 563 
Sold by @itachibot Plasma cell tumors are positive for CD138.
questions.chapter_heading: Multiple Myeloma and Plasma Cell Disorders

questions.question:
Question 4: 551 
Sold by @itachibot What is the most common cytogenetic abnormality in multiple myeloma?
questions.explanation:
The most common cytogenetic abnormality in multiple myeloma is translocation 14q. Cytogenetic abnormalities in multiple myeloma include: • Translocations involving IGH on chromosome 14q - most frequent • Monosomy or partial deletion of chromosome 13 (13q14) - Found by FISH (nearly half the cases) • Translocation of the IgH occurs frequently with cyclin D1 on chromosome 11q and cyclin D3 on 
chromosome 6p • Deletions of chromosome 17p involving TP53 tumor-suppressor locus Translocations with cyclin D1 are associated with a good outcome, whereas deletion of 17p and 
t(4;14) portend an aggressive course.
questions.chapter_heading: Multiple Myeloma and Plasma Cell Disorders

questions.question: Question 5: Which cytokine is an important growth factor for plasma cells in multiple myeloma?
questions.explanation:
The proliferation and survival of plasma cells are dependent on several cytokines, most notably 
IL-6. It is an important growth factor for plasma cells. It is produced by the tumor cells themselves and 
by resident marrow stromal cells. IL6, along with other cytokines, promotes osteoclastic activity 
and lytic bone lesions. High serum levels of IL-6 are seen in patients with active disease and are 
associated with a poor prognosis.
questions.chapter_heading: Multiple Myeloma and Plasma Cell Disorders

questions.question:
Question 6: Which of the following is the most common monoclonal immunoglobulin seen in patients 
with myeloma?
questions.explanation:
The most common monoclonal Ig (M protein) in myeloma is IgG (approximately 55% of patients), 
followed by IgA (approximately 25% of cases). The immunosecretory disorders are a diverse group of diseases associated with the proliferation of 
an abnormal clone of immunoglobulin-synthesizing, terminally differentiated B cells. These 
disorders include: • Multiple myeloma (MM) and its variants • Plasmacytoma • Waldenstrom macroglobulinemia • Monoclonal gammopathy of undetermined significance • Monoclonal Ig deposition diseases - Includes primary amyloidosis and nonamyloidotic types. The immunoglobulin can be complete or can be composed of either heavy or light chains and is 
termed M-(monoclonal) protein. Most myelomas are associated with more than 3 gm/dL of serum 564 
Sold by @itachibot immunoglobulin. Myelomas expressing IgM, IgD, or IgE occur, but they are rare.
questions.chapter_heading: Multiple Myeloma and Plasma Cell Disorders

questions.question: Question 7: In patients with multiple myeloma, lytic lesions are most commonly seen in which bone?
questions.explanation:
Lytic bony lesions in myeloma patients are most commonly seen in the vertebrae. Multiple myeloma usually presents as destructive plasma cell tumors involving the axial skeleton. 
The bones most commonly affected (in descending order of frequency) are: • Vertebral column • Ribs • Skull • Pelvis • Femur • Clavicle • Scapula Pathologic fractures are common in this condition. The bone lesions appear radiographically as 
punched-out defects, usually 1 to 4 cm in diameter. The image given below shows osteoblastic lesions of vertebra in multiple myeloma.
questions.chapter_heading: Multiple Myeloma and Plasma Cell Disorders

questions.question:
Question 8: 552 
Sold by @itachibot Which substance is responsible for the marked increase in bone resorption and 
hypercalcemia in patients with multiple myeloma?
questions.explanation:
MIP1 secreted by myeloma cells is responsible for the marked increase in bone resorption and 
hypercalcemia. Factors produced by neoplastic plasma cells mediate bone destruction, the major pathologic 
feature of multiple myeloma. Of particular importance, myeloma-derived macrophage 565 
Sold by @itachibot inflammatory protein 1 (MIP1) upregulates the expression of the receptor activator of NF-B 
ligand (RANKL) by bone marrow stromal cells, which in turn activates osteoclasts. Other factors released from tumor cells, such as modulators of the Wnt pathway, are potent 
inhibitors of osteoblast function. The net effect is a marked increase in bone resorption, which leads to hypercalcemia and 
pathological fractures. Serum alkaline phosphate levels are normal in multiple myeloma.
questions.chapter_heading: Multiple Myeloma and Plasma Cell Disorders

questions.question:
Question 9: A pathologist observed the following finding in a peripheral blood smear. In patients with 
which of the following conditions is this seen?
questions.explanation:
The given peripheral smear shows rouleaux formation. It is seen in patients with early HIV, SLE, 
and multiple myeloma. 566 
Sold by @itachibot Conditions that cause rouleaux formation are: • Multiple myeloma • Connective tissue disorders like SLE • Early HIV • Infections Rouleaux formation is retarded by albumin.
questions.chapter_heading: Multiple Myeloma and Plasma Cell Disorders

questions.question: Question 10: Which of the following is least likely to be seen in patients with multiple myeloma?
questions.explanation:
Mooser bodies are seen in Typhus fever, not in multiple myeloma. Histopathological findings seen in multiple myeloma: • Dutcher bodies - pale-staining intranuclear inclusions within plasma cells containing Ig, which 
are more common in IgA myeloma (Image below). 567 
Sold by @itachibot • Russell bodies - Hyaline intracytoplasmic inclusions containing Ig • Mott cells/ morula cells - Plasma cells containing multiple grape-like cytoplasmic inclusions 
comprised of Ig • Flame cells - Vermillion-staining, glycogen-rich IgA in cytoplasmic projections • Thesaurocytes - Dilated endoplasmic reticulum cisternae
questions.chapter_heading: Multiple Myeloma and Plasma Cell Disorders

questions.question:
Question 11: The peripheral smear of a patient diagnosed with multiple myeloma is shown below. What 
does the marked structure contain?
questions.explanation:
The given image shows a Mott cell which is a plasma cell with globular cytoplasmic inclusions 
containing immunoglobulins called Russell bodies. Inclusions containing Ig are frequently seen in the cytoplasm (Russell bodies) or the nucleus 
(Dutcher bodies) of some of the plasma cells in myeloma. 568 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.chapter_heading: Multiple Myeloma and Plasma Cell Disorders

questions.question:
Question 12: The marked finding in plasma cells is due to: 554 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The marked finding is perinuclear hof (perinuclear clearing) in plasma cells. It occurs due to a 
prominent Golgi apparatus. Plasma cell characteristics include: • Eccentric nuclei • Moderate to abundant basophilic cytoplasm • Pale perinuclear hof, representing the Golgi zone The image given below shows plasma cells with perinuclear hof. 569 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.chapter_heading: Multiple Myeloma and Plasma Cell Disorders

questions.question:
Question 13: A 60-year-old male presented with a history of intractable diarrhea. Based on the histological 
image shown below which of the following is the most appropriate diagnosis:
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario points to the diagnosis of multiple myeloma. The image shows Russell bodies which are eosinophilic, large, homogeneous 
immunoglobulin-containing inclusions usually found in a plasma cell undergoing excessive 
synthesis of immunoglobulins. Russell bodies are distended endoplasmic reticulum. Globular inclusions are Russell bodies (if cytoplasmic) and Dutcher bodies (if nuclear). The below image shows Russell bodies:
questions.chapter_heading: Multiple Myeloma and Plasma Cell Disorders

questions.question:
Question 14: A patient with pallor and pathological fracture is diagnosed with multiple myeloma. Which of 
the following is not a kidney finding of such patients?
questions.explanation:
Wire-loop lesions are seen in systemic lupus erythematosus and not in multiple myeloma. Renal insufficiency occurs in half the patients with multiple myeloma and several factors are 
responsible for it. They develop acute kidney injury with ologuria and chronic kidney disease. 
Tubular casts, amyloidosis, and renal tubular necrosis are all described in the myeloma kidneys. Features of myeloma kidney: • Bence–Jones proteinuria and cast nephropathy - The main cause of renal dysfunction is related 
to Bence–Jones (light-chain) proteinuria. Ig light chains are directly toxic to epithelial cells. 
Bence-Jones proteins form large, histologically distinct tubular casts that obstruct the tubular 
lumens and induce a characteristic inflammatory reaction (light-chain cast nephropathy). • Amyloidosis of AL type, formed from free light chains (usually of  type) • Light-chain deposition disease - light chains (usually of  type) deposit in the glomerular 
basement membrane and mesangium causing a glomerulopathy and in tubular basement 
membranes, which may cause tubulointerstitial nephritis. 570 
Sold by @itachibot • Hypercalcemia - Nephrocalcinosis
questions.chapter_heading: Multiple Myeloma and Plasma Cell Disorders

questions.question: Question 15: What do Bence Jones proteins in the urine of multiple myeloma patients represent?
questions.explanation:
Bence Jones proteins are immunoglobulin light chains (paraproteins) produced by neoplastic 
plasma cells. They can be kappa (most of the time) or lambda. The light chains can be immunoglobulin 
fragments or single homogeneous immunoglobulins. In patients with plasma cell tumors, the level 
of free light chains is usually elevated. One of the light chains is elevated with a reduction in the 
other. Free light chains are excreted in the urine because they are small in size, where they are 
referred to as Bence Jones proteins. Tests for Bence Jones protein are: • Heat test • Urine protein electrophoresis • Immunofixation
questions.chapter_heading: Multiple Myeloma and Plasma Cell Disorders

questions.question:
Question 16: Hyperviscosity symptoms in patients with multiple myeloma occur due to which of the 
following types of M protein?
questions.explanation:
Symptoms related to hyperviscosity in multiple myeloma occurs due to excessive production of M 
proteins, usually of IgG3 or IgA subtype. Waldenstrom macroglobulinemia (IgM myeloma) is the most common cause for hyperviscosity 
syndrome due to excess IgM paraprotein. Less commonly, it also occurs in multiple myeloma 
(with myeloma proteins IgA and IgG3 types) and connective tissue diseases. Normal relative serum viscosity ranges from 1.4 to 1.8 units. Symptoms are not seen at <4, and 
hyperviscosity syndrome typically requires a viscosity of >5 units. Clinical features include: • Visual impairment • Neurologic problems • Bleeding • Cryoglobulinemia
questions.chapter_heading: Multiple Myeloma and Plasma Cell Disorders

questions.question:
Question 17: Multiple myeloma patients associated with which type of M protein has the highest risk of 
renal insufficiency? 556 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
IgD type of multiple myeloma has the highest risk of renal insufficiency. IgG is most commonly involved in multiple myeloma. The higher the level of IgG, the more is the 
risk of renal failure in patients with multiple myeloma overall. But the rarer IgD predominant 
multiple myeloma has the highest risk of renal insufficiency when compared to other types. 571 
Sold by @itachibot IgD type multiple myeloma is a rare type of multiple myeloma. In this condition, there is 
monoclonal IgD in serum. On serum electrophoresis, there is no or absent M spike. There is a 
higher incidence of extramedullary involvement, amyloidosis, proteinuria, and renal insufficiency 
in comparison to IgG or IgA type multiple myeloma. It has a poor prognosis.
questions.chapter_heading: Multiple Myeloma and Plasma Cell Disorders

questions.question:
Question 18: Which of the following tumor markers is least likely to be positive in a patient with multiple 
myeloma?
questions.explanation:
Plasma-cell tumors are least likely to show positivity for CD 21. They are positive for CD138, an adhesion molecule also known as syndecan-1, CD 38, and often 
express CD56.
questions.chapter_heading: Multiple Myeloma and Plasma Cell Disorders

questions.question:
Question 19: Which of the following is not considered as a myeloma-defining event, according to the 
revised criteria for the diagnosis of multiple myeloma?

options.a: More than one focal lesionon MRI of 5 mm or more
options.b: 60% or more clonal plasma cells on bone marrow examination
options.d: Serum involved/uninvolved free light-chain ratio of 100 or greater

questions.explanation:
Biopsy-proven plasmacytoma is not considered as a myeloma-defining event (MDE). Revised International Myeloma Working Group criteria for the diagnosis of multiple myeloma: Clonal bone marrow plasma cells 10% (or) Biopsy-proven bony or extramedullary plasmacytoma. AND Myeloma defining events (one or more): Evidence of end-organ damage attributable to the 
underlying plasma cell proliferative disorder, specifically- • HyperCalcemia: Serum calcium level >1 mg/dL higher than the upper limit of normal or >11 
mg/dL • Renal insufficiency: Creatinine clearance <40 mL/min or serum creatinine >2 mg/dL • Anemia: Hemoglobin level of >20 g/L (2gm/dl) below the lowest limit of normal, or Hb <10 
g/dL • Bone lesions: One or more osteolytic lesions on skeletal radiography, computed tomography 
(CT), or positron emission tomography (PET)/CT. • Any one or more biomarkers of malignancy: Clonal bone marrow plasma cells 60%; Serum 
involved/uninvolved free light-chain ratio  100; >1 focal lesion on magnetic resonance imaging 
(MRI) that is  5 mm in size.
questions.chapter_heading: Multiple Myeloma and Plasma Cell Disorders

questions.question:
Question 20: A 60-year-old lady presents with complaints of pallor, recurrent UTI, and bone pain in lower 
limbs. Peripheral smear shows rouleaux formation. X-ray done is given below. Which is the 
best immunohistochemical marker for this condition? 557 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario and X-ray showing lytic lesions on the bone are suggestive of multiple 
myeloma. The best immunohistochemical (IHC) marker for this condition is cyclin D1. Multiple myeloma is associated with diverse translocations involving the IgH locus; 
overexpression of D cyclins—cyclin D1 and D3. Plasma cell tumors are positive for CD138 and 
often express CD56. 572 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.chapter_heading: Multiple Myeloma and Plasma Cell Disorders

questions.question:
Question 21: A patient diagnosed with multiple myeloma develops features of restrictive cardiomyopathy 
and macroglossia. Which of the following amyloid is responsible for this?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of amyloidosis. The amyloid of the AL type is produced 
from free Ig light chains secreted by a monoclonal population of plasma cells and its deposition is 
associated with multiple myeloma.
questions.chapter_heading: Multiple Myeloma and Plasma Cell Disorders

questions.question: Question 22: What is the most common cause of death in patients with myeloma?
questions.explanation: Infections are the most common cause of death in patients with myeloma. Complications of multiple myeloma include: • Infections • Renal failure • Cardiac failure • Hypercalcemia • Anemia
questions.chapter_heading: Multiple Myeloma and Plasma Cell Disorders

questions.question:
Question 23: A 60-year-old man presents with complaints of fatigue, pain over the ribs, and confusion. Lab 
investigations reveal anemia, hypercalcemia, and increased serum creatinine. X-ray shows 
lytic lesions on the bones. Which of the following is the most powerful prognostic indicator of 
this condition at the time of diagnosis?

options.a: Number of myeloma cells in the marrow

questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of multiple myeloma. The most powerful prognostic 
indicator of this condition at the time of diagnosis is serum  2 microglobulin. Beta-2 microglobulin is a low-molecular-weight protein found on the surface of all nucleated cells. 
It is the light chain of the HLA histocompatibility complex.
questions.chapter_heading: Multiple Myeloma and Plasma Cell Disorders

questions.question:
Question 24: Which of the following is not associated with poor prognosis in a patient with multiple 
myeloma?
questions.explanation:
t(11;14) is associated with a good prognosis in patients with myeloma. t(4;14), high serum beta-2 microglobulin, and low serum albumin are all poor prognostic factors 
in myeloma.
questions.chapter_heading: Multiple Myeloma and Plasma Cell Disorders

questions.question:
Question 25: A 70-year-old man presents with chronic low back pain. On examination, he has pallor and 
bony tenderness. A skeletal radiographic survey reveals several punched-out lytic lesions. 
Serum protein electrophoresis shows an M band in the gamma globulin region. Which of the 
following is not associated with a poor prognosis in this condition?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is highly suggestive of multiple myeloma. Translocations involving 
cyclin D1 are associated with a good outcome in this condition. t(14;16), deletions of 17p, and t(14;20) are associated with a more aggressive course. 573 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.chapter_heading: Multiple Myeloma and Plasma Cell Disorders

questions.question:
Question 26: Which among these is not diagnostic of monoclonal gammopathy of undetermined 
significance? 559 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
Bence–Jones proteinuria is not diagnostic of monoclonal gammopathy of undetermined 
significance (MGUS) because it is seen in multiple myeloma also. MGUS is the most common monoclonal gammopathy. Diagnostic criteria of MGUS according to International Myeloma Working Group guidelines 
(2014): • Serum monoclonal protein <3g/dL • Clonal bone marrow plasma cells < 10% • Absence of end-organ damage such as hypercalcemia, renal failure, anemia and bone lesions 
(CRAB) • No amyloidosis The three distinct clinical types of MGUS are: • Non-IgM MGUS: • Most common subtype of MGUS • Approximately 1% of patients with MGUS develop a symptomatic plasma cell neoplasm, usually 
multiple myeloma, per year • IgM MGUS: • IgM MGUS accounts for approximately 15% of MGUS cases • It can progress to Waldenström macroglobulinemia, but progression to multiple myeloma is rare • Bence–Jones proteinuria has been reported in approximately 20% of these cases • Light chain MGUS (LC-MGUS): • LC-MGUS is a unique subtype of MGUS in which there is no immunoglobulin heavy-chain 
component • Urinary M protein <500 mg/24 hour • LC-MGUS may progress to light-chain smoldering multiple myeloma (idiopathic Bence–Jones 
proteinuria) and to light-chain multiple myeloma
questions.chapter_heading: Multiple Myeloma and Plasma Cell Disorders

questions.question:
Question 27: A patient with complaints of blurred vision, bleeding gums, and tingling sensation over the 
extremities is diagnosed with lymphoplasmacytic lymphoma. Which of the following 
immunoglobulins is this condition associated with?
questions.explanation:
High levels of IgM are seen in lymphoplasmacytic lymphoma. In lymphoplasmacytic lymphoma, high levels of IgM lead to symptoms related to hyperviscosity of 
the blood. This is known as Waldenstrom’s macroglobulinemia. ‘M’ or monoclonal spike is seen in 
this condition. Here, it is caused by IgM; in multiple myeloma, it is caused by IgG. It is 
characterized by the absence of lytic lesions and normal serum calcium levels. 574 
Sold by @itachibot IgM greatly increases the viscosity of the blood, giving rise to a hyperviscosity syndrome 
characterized by the following: • Visual impairment • Neurologic problems • Bleeding • Cryoglobulinemia The normal relative viscosity of the serum is 1.8. Hyperviscosity is seen in: • Multiple myeloma • Waldenstrom’s macroglobulinemia • Cryoglobulinemia • Myeloproliferative disorders
questions.chapter_heading: Multiple Myeloma and Plasma Cell Disorders

questions.question:
Question 28: A 40-year-old man is diagnosed with lymphoplasmacytic lymphoma. Which of the following 
genes is mutated in this condition?
questions.explanation:
Virtually all cases of lymphoplasmacytic lymphoma are associated with acquired mutations in 
MYD88. The most common cytogenetic abnormality associated with lymphoplasmacytic lymphoma is 
deletion of 6q.
questions.chapter_heading: Multiple Myeloma and Plasma Cell Disorders

questions.question: Question 29: Which of the following is not seen in patients with Waldenstrom macroglobulinemia?

options.a: M spike in serum protein electrophoresis
options.d: Absence of lytic lesions on imaging

questions.explanation:
Serum calcium levels remain normal in Waldenström macroglobulinemia. Waldenström macroglobulinemia is a syndrome characterised by the following: • Hyperviscosity syndrome due to high levels of IgM • Most commonly occurs in association with lymphoplasmacytic lymphoma • ‘M’ or monoclonal spike • Absence of lytic lesions • Normal serum calcium levels • Diffuse marrow infiltration by plasma cells, plasmacytoid lymphocytes, and lymphocytes (all 
from the same clone) • Cells do not form tumor masses or produce lytic lesions • Lymphocytes commonly contain Dutcher bodies (intranuclear inclusions) • Bence–Jones proteins in 20–30% 575 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.chapter_heading: Multiple Myeloma and Plasma Cell Disorders

questions.question:
Question 30: 560 
Sold by @itachibot Which of the following is the most common site for extramedullary plasmacytoma?
questions.explanation:
Extramedullary plasmacytomas are seen in the upper respiratory tract. Most of them are seen in 
the nasopharynx, oropharynx, sinuses, and larynx. Plasmacytoma is a tumor of plasma cells of bony or soft tissue. It can occur anywhere in the body 
without evidence of systemic disease.
questions.chapter_heading: Multiple Myeloma and Plasma Cell Disorders

questions.question: Question 31: What is Seligmann's disease?
questions.explanation:
- heavy chain disease (HCD) is known as Seligmann's disease. There are three heavy chain diseases: • - heavy chain disease - Seligmann's disease • - heavy chain disease - Franklin's disease • - heavy chain disease - Associated with light-chain secretion (Bence–Jones proteinuria) in a few 
cases
questions.chapter_heading: Multiple Myeloma and Plasma Cell Disorders

questions.question:
Question 32: A 60-year-old man presents with a history of bone pain, weakness, and loss of weight for 3 
years. On examination, enlarged lymph nodes and organomegaly are noted. Peripheral smear 
shows 22% plasma cells, which are -chain restricted. Serum IgE level is elevated. X-ray 
image of the lumbar vertebra shows lytic punched-out lesions. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario points to the diagnosis of plasma cell leukemia. In this case, the 
peripheral blood smear shows 22% of plasma cells and presents with organomegaly. Plasma cell leukemia is defined by the observation in blood of more than 20% clonal plasma cells 
by differential count of the leucocytes or by counting more than 2 × 109 per liter circulating clonal 
plasma cells. Plasma cell leukemia (PCL) is a rare and aggressive form of leukemia and plasma cell 
dyscrasia. PCL can be divided into primary PCL (PCL) and secondary PCL (sPCL) following 
previously diagnosed multiple myeloma (MM); the latter typically occurring at a late and 
advanced stage of MM. Patients with plasma cell leukemia are more likely to have extramedullary involvement of liver 
and spleen, causing organomegaly than in multiple myeloma. (Option A) 576 
Sold by @itachibot Myelodysplastic Syndrome, Myeloproliferative Syndromes and Histiocytosis
questions.chapter_heading: Multiple Myeloma and Plasma Cell Disorders
